wrap-up.title: The Magical Revolution of the Reincarnated Princess and the Genius Young Lady
wrap-up.text: At its core this is a queer story about reducing the divide between commonfolk and nobility, with a heavy focus on the characters' emotional struggles as they discover and pursue their aspirations.
wrap-up.line2: As someone who has read the novels, this adaptation was everything I could have hoped for. The animation and voicework was great all-around, the writing was well-adapted (especially in the places where the novels had pacing issues!), and they didn't water down the themes as I had feared. I absolutely recommend it.

wrap-up.title: Tsurune: The Linking Shot
wrap-up.text: Season 1 was already great, but this sequel is even better and easily makes for one of the best sports anime out there.

wrap-up.title: The Eminence in Shadow
wrap-up.text: A ridiculous, comically-edgy isekai about a kid living his dream of being a background character who's secretly a mysterious all-powerful edgelord operating in the shadows.
wrap-up.line2: Great, if you can buy into the premise.

wrap-up.title: Welcome to Demon School! Iruma-kun s3
wrap-up.line2: There's often not much to say about sequels like this. It was good before, it is still good now. I appreciate that this season took the time to develop the side characters more.

wrap-up.title: Trigun Stampede
wrap-up.text: Orange once again demonstrates the potential of CG anime. I wouldn't rate it as high as Land of the Lustrous, but it's pretty darn good.
wrap-up.line2: I do have minor complaints about some of the action sequences, but I would still recommend this regardless of whether you're familiar with the original material.

wrap-up.title: Blue Lock
wrap-up.text: It's like a death game but instead of dying you just don't get to play pro soccer.
wrap-up.line2: A silly and overdramatic, but still quite good sports anime.

wrap-up.title: The Angel Next Door Spoils Me Rotten
wrap-up.text: A wholesome romance about two people who respect each other too much.
wrap-up.line2: I tend to enjoy contrived-premise romcoms. Like sure, the setup is a bit silly, but that doesn't detract from some really great interactions and characterization.

wrap-up.title: In/Spectre s2
wrap-up.text: Better than the first season. Its strengths are still in the quirky protagonist and her problem-solving methods which make this more than a typical supernatural detective show.

wrap-up.title: Kaina of the Great Snow Sea
wrap-up.text: Very interesting setting with good (but not great) CG animation and a somewhat clumsy story.
wrap-up.line2: I enjoyed it, but there are few situations where I'd recommend it.

wrap-up.title: D4DJ All Mix
wrap-up.text: The decision to split the focus between all the units meant that none of the characters or dynamics got to shine.
wrap-up.line2: Unlike the first season I would only recommend this to people already invested in the game; there is very little here for anime-only viewers, and even for people familiar with the series the episodes are very hit-and-miss.

wrap-up.title: The Reincarnation of the Strongest Exorcist in Another World
wrap-up.text: Just good enough to keep me from getting bored. A decent isekai to turn your brain off to, if you don't mind some really bad CG every once in a while.

wrap-up.title: High Card
wrap-up.text: 52 cards, each granting the holder a unique power. Interesting and stylish premise, but extremely generic and predictable execution.
wrap-up.line2: It just didn't do anything special and had very few redeeming elements.

wrap-up.title: Reborn to Master the Blade
wrap-up.text: When I was looking for light novels with female protagonists this was near the bottom of many lists, and now I see why; the characters are fine, but the story and setting are a bit of a mess.
wrap-up.line2: I appreciate that it's at least trying to do something different, but I honestly only finished this through sheer inertia.
